item.title: A Summary of Recent "Social Evaluation" Research
item.description: 1 Motivation 2. Biblio-Analysis 2.1 Selection Criteria 2.2 Central Sources and Keywords 3 Classic Papers 3.1 Top Citations 3.2 Summary of Top-cited Papers 1 Motivation The goal of this post is to analyze and review the “social evaluation” research tracing back to Zuckerman (1999)1. The analysis/review is based on hand-collected papers that directly and indirectly cite Zuckerman (1999). The review is not intended to be comprehensive but to understand the central ideas on the topic developed by management/sociology scholars in the past 20 years.

item.title: Optimal Positioning for Firms and Individuals
item.description: Imagine you are invited to a party. Probably you want to get noticed by other partygoers. Or at least you want to be recognized as a cool person by those who you are interested in and care about. The “coolness” will result in some social benefits you desire. This scene is about “social evaluation,” which applies to both individuals and firms. On the social evaluation stage, because there are peer actors (competitors) joining you, you want to stand out of the crowd to impress your audiences (customers and suppliers).
